subject: RE: [junit] Do we need to convince management of the benefits of unit    tests?
msgSnippet: ... In the system I m currently working on over half the classes were obsolete, POC or due to projects that hadn t gone live . Half the object model relates
messageBody:
> > We make so many descisions we don't ask permission for like "is it ok to
> > remove this dead code?
>
> You don't?! I see it all the time. More specifically, I see people
> acting as though they do /not/ have permission to remove dead code. "If
> it ain't broke, don't fix it" and "Don't touch it; it might break"

In the system I'm currently working on over half the classes were obsolete,
POC or due to projects that hadn't gone "live". Half the object model
relates to functions that the original lead worked on that were parked (the
project was descoped 2 years ago). The code has large blocks scattered
throughout that look like

boolean projectXEnabled = false;

if (projectXEnabled == true) {
...
...
...
}

I have deleted more code (methods, classes, entire packages) in 18 months
than I have written in that time, and I've rewritten most of the remaining
live functionality.

The original lead actively fought against using source control and automated
builds (ant) which may explain some of it (no source control = can't delete
it we might need it) but that just opens up the question about why was he
employed for so long and why is he now back in the company in another
technical lead position?

Michael Rutherfurd
